importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The study tracks the rise in eye injuries from 2021 to 2024, showing a 405-case-per-year increase in pickleball-related eye injuries.
The study estimates that eye injury cases peaked in 2024, highlighting a growing public health concern tied to rising pickleball participation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2021 to 2024 saw a dramatic rise in pickleball-related eye injuries, with an estimated 405 additional cases annually.

keyTakeAways: The incidence of pickleball-related eye injuries has increased significantly from 2021 to 2024, with 405 more cases per year.
The majority of injuries (70%) occur in adults aged 50 and older, contrary to expectations that younger players are most at risk.
Injuries are caused by being hit by the ball, paddle, or falling due to the fast-paced and small-court nature of the game.
Standardized eye protection guidelines could reduce up to 90% of sports-related eye injuries, similar to those in squash.
Players are often unaware of the risks, and lack of awareness is a major reason for non-use of protective eyewear.
Recommended eye protection must be made of shatter-resistant polycarbonate and meet the ASTM F3164 standard.
Professional pickleball athletes could serve as role models to encourage safer practices and eye protection use.
Current data relies on emergency department reports and has a small sample size, limiting generalizability.
The injuries can be life-changing, emphasizing the importance of simple, preventive interventions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pickleball, a rapidly growing sport in the U.S. with nearly 20 million participants, is linked to a significant rise in eye injuries—up by 405 cases annually from 2021 to 2024. The study published in JAMA Ophthalmology found that 70% of injuries occur in adults aged 50 or older, with causes including being struck by the ball, paddle, or falling due to the game’s fast pace and small court. Experts such as Dr. Corey Lacher and Dr. Daniel Henick emphasize that standardized eye protection guidelines—especially those meeting ASTM F3164 and made from shatter-resistant polycarbonate—could prevent up to 90% of injuries. Despite strong recommendations, many players remain unaware of the risks, and the lack of awareness and user-friendly options remain barriers to adoption. USA Pickleball has not responded to calls for policy changes, highlighting a critical gap in safety infrastructure for the sport.
title: Pickleball Eye Injuries Are on the Rise
